content.question: Identical Cylinders <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> each have mass <math alttext="lowercase m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math> and are partially filled with different fluids. The fluid in Cylinder <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> has a volume <math alttext="V" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>V</mi></math> and the fluid in Cylinder <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> has a volume <math alttext="2 V" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>V</mi></math>. When Cylinder <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is placed on a scale calibrated to measure mass, the scale reads a mass <math alttext="uppercase M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>M</mi></math>. When Cylinder <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is placed on the scale, the scale reads a mass <math alttext="2 uppercase M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>M</mi></math>. A student claims that this indicates the densities of the two fluids are equal. Is the claim correct? Why or why not?

choices.label: Yes, because the ratio of mass to volume of the two fluids is the same.
Yes, because the containers are identical.
No, because the student neglected to account for the effect that the mass of the cylinders has on the scale reading.
No, because the student neglected to account for the total volume of the cylinders.

content.answer: No, because the student neglected to account for the effect that the mass of the cylinders has on the scale reading.

skill.text: 3.C: Justify or support a claim using evidence from experimental data, physical representations, or physical principles or laws.
